15. Since March 2025, DOL has taken a series of actions to shut down Job Corps.
16. For example, DOL halted applicant background checks, which effectively prevented new enrollment, as students must pass a background check when they are admitted.
17. On April 11, 2025, DOL discontinued dedicated student Career Transition Readiness (“CTR”) programs and student medical testing requirements.
18. On April 23, 2025, all pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements except for three were abruptly canceled.
19. On April 25, 2025, DOL released a “Job Corps Transparency Report,” which applies a flawed methodology and reflects selective and inaccurate performance measures, costs, and statistics.
20. On April 30, 2025, DOL effectively terminated its provision of internet service to Job Corps campuses.
21. On May 2, 2025, Russell T. Vought, the Director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, submitted President Trump’s recommendations on discretionary funding levels to the Senate for fiscal year 2026.
22. On May 29, 2025, DOL had a call with all Job Corps operators to announce its plan to implement stop work orders on all Job Corps contracts nationwide.

extracted.value: DOL's actions to eliminate Job Corps, including halting applicant background checks (March 2025), discontinuing Career Transition Readiness programs (April 11, 2025), canceling Job Corps procurements (April 23, 2025), releasing a flawed Transparency Report (April 25, 2025), terminating internet services (April 30, 2025), and announcing nationwide shutdown via termination notices on May 29, 2025, causing displacement of students, business destruction, and job losses

It is further ORDERED that Defendants, their agents, and all persons acting in concert or participation with Defendants are ENJOINED from enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to the closure of the private Job Corps centers, including the stop work orders and termination and non-renewal notices delivered to Job Corps center operators starting May 29, 2025; from issuing, enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to any shutdown tasks, job terminations, or student removals; and from taking any further action to eliminate the Job Corps program without Congressional authorization.

evidence.text: Status Report re: settlement Document filed by National Job Corps Association
Congress created Jobs Corps in the Economic Opportunity Act (“EOA”) of 1964, an effort of President Lyndon B. Johnson’s War on Poverty, to tackle the problem of youth unemployment.
In 2014, the Workplace Innovation and Opportunity Act (“WIOA”) stated that: “There shall be within the Department of Labor a ‘Job Corps.’” 29 U.S.C. § 3193 (emphasis added).

extracted.value: Workplace Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) (29 U.S.C. § 3193)

evidence.text: The Impoundment Control Act of 1974 explicitly prohibits the Executive Branch from impounding appropriated funds without following certain procedures. 2 U.S.C. § 681 et seq.

extracted.value: Impoundment Control Act of 1974 (2 U.S.C. § 681 et seq.)
